results.title: Full of Life
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Coping (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This is part of series designed for use by upper secondary students and school leavers. The transition from being a student to a working young adult seeking independence can be fraught with unexpected responsibilities and financial problems. This program describes what to expect once you begin working, together with hints on basic survival techniques and personal budgeting.

results.title: Keep moving (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
Promotes the importance of regular exercise including the positive effects of physical exertion and eating the correct foods. Designed to trigger young people’s interest in wanting to include exercise as a regular part of a balanced lifestyle.

results.title: Outside in...Skin (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program looks at the various things that affect our skin. Topics covered include the structure of the skin, the purpose of the skin and the things that influence the state of our skins such as diet, hygiene, age and sun. This program aims to encourage young people to adopt a healthy, balanced way of living. Rated: G.

results.title: Coping - Full of Life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program aims to teach young people the mechanisms for coping. Through this program we learn that fun for fun’s sake is an important part of life, that it is important to establish a list of priorities and accept that some things cannot be done, and that it often helps to talk about our problems with someone. Rated: G

results.title: Fuelling Up
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program aims to teach young people that diet does not mean the complete denial of nice things to eat, but rather the controlled, planned intake of good quality food - the fuel necessary to power life. Rated: G

results.title: Frontline. Series 2. One big family. Working class man. Divide the community, multiply the ratings. Changing the face of current affairs.
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Frontline TV Prod
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
In “One big family” ratings are down but the new network promo takes first priority. Mike attempts to broaden his image by becoming a “Working class man.” The Frontline team are investigating ethnic violence in “Divide the community, multiply the ratings”. A consultant is called in to help ratings in “Changing the face of current affairs.”
results.title_for_label: Frontline. Series 2. One big family. Working class man. Divide the community, multiply the ratings. Changing the face of current affairs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Frontline TV Prod

results.title: Frontline. Series 1. Desert angel. The Siege. We ain't got dames.
results.creator_credit: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontline”.
Three episodes from the highly acclaimed Australian comedy show which exposes life behind the cameras of a popular current affairs program. A beautiful aid worker believed missing in the desert is found and the Frontline staff attempt to get an exclusive in “Desert angel.” Meanwhile, another network tries to poach legendary anchorman Mike Moore. A gunman takes several hostages in a remote farmhouse, and Frontline’s questionable methods to gain a scoop boosts their ratings in “The Siege.” Frontline tries to woo back female viewers by ditching their Friday night funnyman in “We ain’t got dames.”
results.title_for_label: Frontline. Series 1. Desert angel. The Siege. We ain’t got dames.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Sitch, Jane Kennedy, Tom Gleisner, Santo Cilauro, ABC-TV (Australia) and Frontline Television Productions
